question_text: Why does turbophoresis not require an additional force term in the particle momentum equation, and how is this phenomenon naturally captured through the modeling of the fluid velocity seen Us(t)?
standard_answer: Turbophoresis, the net migration of particles from high-turbulence to low-turbulence regions, is inherently captured by the standard particle momentum equation without requiring additional force terms. The phenomenon emerges naturally from the statistical properties of the fluid velocity seen Us(t) and the particle inertia. In inhomogeneous turbulent flows, the distribution of Us(t) varies spatially - in high-turbulence regions, Us(t) exhibits larger fluctuations and broader probability density functions, while in low-turbulence regions, the fluctuations are smaller. Particles with finite inertia (tp > 0) cannot instantaneously respond to these velocity fluctuations through the drag force (Us - Up)/tp. When particles enter high-turbulence regions, they experience strong, rapidly changing fluid velocities that their inertia prevents them from fully following, causing them to be 'kicked out' toward calmer regions. Conversely, in low-turbulence regions, particles tend to remain since the fluid velocities are more stable. This net flux arises from the spatial correlation between turbulence intensity and the particle response characteristics. Adding an explicit turbophoresis force would constitute double-counting, as the phenomenon is already fully described by the combination of: (1) the spatially varying statistics of Us(t), (2) the drag force mechanism, and (3) particle inertia. The key is that accurate modeling of Us(t) with proper spatial dependence of its statistical moments automatically produces the turbophoretic effect.
